abstract.p: As global biodiversity continues to reduce at an alarming rate, threatened species are increasingly being brought under intensive management or into captivity. However, current conservation management programmes are often impeded by poor animal health and low reproductive success. Microorganisms play vital roles in the growth and maintenance of healthy multicellular organisms, including neurological and immune system development, gut nutrition, and pathogen defence. The microbiome refers to the vast community of microorganisms, and their collective genes, that live on and within a host organism. An imbalance or breakdown of the microbiome may in some cases be associated with severe negative health consequences for the host. Factors such as habitat degradation and transition into captive breeding programmes can significantly alter the microbiome of threatened species, though the effects of such microbial community changes on health, fitness and ultimately survival of the animals remain poorly understood. This perspective article collates important microbiome research in threatened animals from around the world to make a case for the inclusion of microbial research in modern conservation practice.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: More than 13,000 animal species worldwide are currently classified as threatened (i.e. vulnerable, endangered or critically endangered; IUCN, 2012;IUCN, 2018). Saving threatened species requires intensive management, with contemporary conservation strategies including breeding programmes, the establishment of assurance populations, translocation of individuals between populations to enhance genetic variation, and the provisioning of habitat sanctuaries and forest corridors (Kueneman et al., 2016;Stumpf et al., 2016). Many programmes treat or rear threatened species in captive centres with the aim to reintroduce these individuals to their natural habitats and prevent species extinction. However, these efforts can be impeded by limited habitat, disease epidemics, and poor reproductive success in captivity and postrelease (Stumpf et al., 2016;Krynak et al., 2017;Wasimuddin et al., 2017;Yang et al., 2017;Zhao et al., 2017b).

Over the past decade, microbiological research has revealed a glimpse of the integral, largely unforeseen role that microorganisms play in animal health and development. Animals provide a diverse array of habitats for microorganisms to colonise, with virtually all animals harbouring multiple types of microbial taxa. These include bacteria, viruses, archaea and eukaryotic microbes such as fungi and protozoa, which form dynamic communities that interact with host species (McFall-Ngai et al., 2013;Colston and Jackson, 2016). This diversity of microorganisms and their genes, collectively termed the microbiome, plays key functional roles on and within the host body (Mueller and Sachs, 2015). Since the discovery of these complex relationships, the host and its associated microbiome are now often considered as a metaorganism (holobiont) (Bosch and McFall-Ngai, 2011).

From a human health perspective, microbes aid in nutrition, immune system and neurological development, gut maturation, and pathogen defence (reviewed in Wang et al., 2017). The composition of the microbiome also fluctuates according to external factors such as cohabitation, medication and diet (Rodrigues Hoffmann, 2017;Rothschild et al., 2018). Growing appreciation of the importance of the microbiome to human health has seen an explosion of research in this area, T facilitated by rapid developments in cultivation-independent, nextgeneration DNA sequencing technologies (Costello et al., 2009;Turnbaugh et al., 2009;Kuczynski et al., 2011;Gilbert et al., 2016;Lloyd-Price et al., 2017;Gilbert et al., 2018). Our understanding of the various roles of the microbiome in non-human hosts is also expanding, as is our realisation of the possible implications for conservation and management of threatened species (Bahrndorff et al., 2016;Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Stumpf et al., 2016). Principles that apply to the human context are being adapted more widely as we begin to understand that all animals potentially offer selective niches for microbes that provide beneficial roles and relationships for the host. These niches can change in their function and availability as the host organism develops (Williams et al., 2018), enabling the formation of diverse microbial communities and ecosystems which may permit optimal host function and plasticity in response to changing conditions (Zilber- Rosenberg and Rosenberg, 2008).

While a highly dynamic microbiome is apparent in healthy individuals, potentially enabling the holobiont to respond to changing external factors, a breakdown or dysbiosis of the microbial community is often associated with disease (Gilbert et al., 2016;Wagner Mackenzie et al., 2017;McKenzie et al., 2018). Given the essential role of the microbiome in host health, we postulate that microbial community dysbiosis may contribute to the problems afflicting captive and threatened animal species management. The potential role of the microbiome in threatened wildlife health is of increasing concern, particularly in the face of climate change. Here we draw upon research from a variety of taxa ( Fig. 1) to make a case for inclusion of the microbiome in the development of management strategies for threatened animals. While microbiome concepts may not currently be at the forefront of strategies to save threatened animals, consideration and management of host microbiomes may improve host health and therefore survival success. In many cases, the cost of managing the microbiome may be relatively small (e.g. adding prebiotics or probiotics to feed), and the possible gains in host health and function may increase overall programme success.
2. Impact of the microbiome on host health and fitness

div.head: Benefits of the microbiome
div.p: Microbes are found on all eukaryotic organisms, from insects to corals, frogs, birds and bears. Beginning at birth, microbes colonise many niches on and within the host body, with each colonised location displaying a unique assemblage of microbial species and functions. Areas of the body which tend to be colonised by microbes include the surface of the skin, eyes, ears, mouth, nasal cavities, lungs, foregut, hindgut and urogenital cavities such as the vagina. Juvenile humans and chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes schweinfurthii) are known to inherit multiple microbial taxa from their parents Moeller et al., 2016), while infant European pied flycatchers (Ficedula hypoleuca) develop similar microbiomes to their mother in the nest (Goodenough et al., 2017), highlighting the critical role of vertical transmission between generations in establishing initial microbiome communities. Model animal systems have established the mutualistic role that endosymbiotic microorganisms can maintain with the host. For example, aster leafhoppers (Macrosteles quadrilineatus) are nutritionally dependent on two bacterial endosymbionts (Nasuia sp. and Sulcia sp.) which supply essential amino acids, and these microbe-animal relationships have shown patterns of coevolution (Bennett and Moran, 2013). A relationship between facultative symbiont microbes (as opposed to obligate endosymbionts) and host fitness has been demonstrated in pea aphids (Acyrthosiphon pisum) (Li et al., 2016;Qian et al., 2018), wheat aphids (Sitobion miscanthi) (Montllor et al., 2002;Oliver et al., 2003;Scarborough et al., 2005) and ticks (Dermacentor Fig. 1. A selection of threatened animals associated with microbiome research. From top left to bottom right: dugong (vulnerable), Panamanian golden frog (critically endangered), kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (critically endangered), red-shanked douc (endangered), spectacled (Andean) bear (vulnerable), elkhorn coral (Acropora palmata, critically endangered). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) andersoni) (Clayton et al., 2015). In these studies, removal of the symbiont led to significantly reduced host fitness traits including fecundity, adult body weight, and pathogen resistance, though the mechanisms behind these fitness-enhancing associations are not yet understood. While it is acknowledged that facultative microorganisms have a long-standing relationship with multicellular hosts, microbial evolution is inherently selfish. This does not mean that microbiomes do not influence evolution of the host, but caution should be employed when implying that intimate host-microbiome relationships reflect coevolution (see Moran and Sloan (2015) for misconceptions regarding the hologenome, coevolution and phylosymbiosis).

Arguably, the best-known example of microorganisms co-existing with vertebrates is the role of symbiont microbes in herbivore digestion. Mammalian herbivores employ fermentation to break down plant material in a specialised chamber to maximise fibre digestion (Mackie, 2002). While multicellular animals are capable of digesting proteins, lipids and simple sugars through enzymatic breakdown, these enzymes are not able to digest the complex, structural polysaccharides of plants. Conversely, many species of microbes produce unique enzymes that can easily digest plant fibres, albeit much more slowly than other food components, in a process called fermentation. Over millions of years mammalian herbivores have evolved enlarged specialised chambers to house these plant-digesting microbes and facilitate the extended breakdown of plant material (Hobson, 1997;Mackie, 2002). In this relationship the herbivorous host provides its microbial symbionts with habitat and food resources. The microbes provide essential nutrients to the host through the production of fatty acid metabolites as by-products of fermentation. These fatty acids are absorbed and assimilated by the host, providing a substantial portion of their daily energy uptake (see Hobson, 1997). The location of the fermentation chamber can be situated in the foregut region of the stomach (e.g. ruminating even-toed ungulates such as cattle and giraffes, kangaroos and non-human primates) or in the hindgut (e.g. elephants, odd-toed ungulates such as horses and rhinoceros, rodents, koalas), thus creating two functional groups of fermenters. We now know that microbes not only influence digestion, but also play important roles in many biological processes that affect host health and function. Colobine primates, such as the endangered red-shanked douc (Pygathrix nemaeus) and endangered proboscis monkey (Nasalis larvatus), are notable foregut fermenters (Clayton et al., 2018;Hayakawa et al., 2018a). Order Primates is a species-rich mammalian group inhabiting a variety of landscapes from the Neotropics to mountainous Asia. Unfortunately, due to anthropogenic activity more than half of all primate species around the world are threatened with extinction (Estrada et al., 2017). Because of their close ancestral link with humans and conservation status, primate microbiomes are particularly well-studied.

Corals have also been a primary focus for microbiome holobiont studies due to their abundance of associated microorganisms, which can be specific to a given coral species and contribute to essential nutrient cycling and pathogen-defence processes (reviewed in Bourne et al., 2016). Roughly a third of coral reef species have been assigned a conservation status of "elevated risk of extinction", with two Caribbean acroporids on the IUCN red list (Carpenter et al., 2008). The alarming decline in coral reef health globally has provided impetus for understanding the acclimation and adaption processes that may contribute to resilience in reef ecosystems faced with rapid environmental change, with particular focus on the potential role of the microbiome in these resilience processes (Glasl et al., 2016;Damjanovic et al., 2017;Peixoto et al., 2017). Corals possess an innate immune system, but also rely on niche occupation and antimicrobial activities of their microbiome to prevent pathogen invasion and proliferation (Ritchie, 2006;Nissimov et al., 2009;Shnit-Orland and Kushmaro, 2009). These microbial communities are not static: like all holobionts, the coral microbiome changes composition with age, health, habitat and environmental fluctuations (Littman et al., 2009; Sharp et al., 2012; Bourne et al., 2016; Chu and Vollmer, 2016). The intimate relationship between corals and their microbiomes suggests that maintenance of a 'healthy' microbial community may confer upon the host increased fitness and resistance to pathogens or environmental disruption. For example, the coral Oculina patagonica developed resistance to a bacterial pathogen, Vibrio shiloi, which was previously responsible for bleaching in this species (Reshef et al., 2006;Nissimov et al., 2009). Resistance to the pathogen was attributed to a beneficial microbiome shift (Nissimov et al., 2009). These observations gave rise to the 'Coral Probiotic Hypothesis' (CPH) (Reshef et al., 2006), developed by Rosenberg et al. (2007) to propose that "a dynamic relationship exists between symbiotic microorganisms and environmental conditions which brings about the selection of the most advantageous coral holobiont". The ability of the coral microbiome to shift or alter in response to external pressures such as rising seawater temperature, providing an adaptive flexibility to the holobiont, has been reviewed in Bang et al. (2018). This concept was reinforced after antibiotic treatment increased coral sensitivity to V. shiloi infection (Mills et al., 2013), implying that microbes essential to holobiont pathogen defence were removed in this process. Recently Ziegler et al. (2017) found that fragments of Acropora hyacinthus corals transplanted to warmer, more variable environments displayed microbiome shifts that coincided with increased thermotolerance. However, host-microbe interactions at the cellular level still need to be elucidated to determine whether patterns of host-derived resilience are directly linked to the microbiome, or only reflect casual associations. Peixoto et al. (2017) propose using the term BMC (Beneficial Microorganisms for Corals) in place of the CPH to reflect the current lack of understanding regarding the mechanisms by which the microbiome may support coral health. The authors employ BMC to identify and define microbes that play key roles in coral health and which could subsequently be manipulated to improve coral resilience. Considering reefs represent one of the most threatened ecosystems on the planet from rapid climate change (Hughes et al., 2017), understanding their adaptive potential has become a priority.

div.head: The concept of dysbiosis
div.p: Despite the apparent ability of the microbiome to 'collaborate' beneficially with the host, there are also instances in which the host experiences negative side-effects from direct or indirect interaction with its microbial community. Research in humans has indicated that the onset or development of numerous diseases may be potentiated by the microbiome (Belkaid and Hand, 2014;McLean et al., 2015;Wagner Mackenzie et al., 2017). The immune system is built by genetically coded factors and develops through learned interactions with the gut microbiota and invading pathogens (see Nishida et al., 2018). A major function of the immune system is to tightly regulate and maintain our microbial communities, and prevent adverse activities or responses that would endanger the host. These functions become impaired, however, when the immune response is uncontrolled or misdirected, leading to instances of inflammation and allergies (Belkaid and Hand, 2014). Moreover, some members of the microbiome that were previously beneficial to the host can initiate a pathogenic response when left unregulated by a compromised immune system (Xu et al., 2018). These relationships can also be altered by externally introduced factors, such as medication or diet (David et al., 2014, diet in non-human primates reviewed in Clayton et al., 2018). Perturbation or disruption of our microbial communities is recognised as dysbiosis, potentially reducing microbiome function and yielding a less efficient and resistant microbiome that is susceptible to infection and disease (Amato et al., 2013;Apprill et al., 2014;Amato et al., 2016, reviewed in Gilbert et al., 2018. However, dysbiosis has often been used as a blanket term to describe any change or imbalance in microbiome composition, leading to backlash and controversy around specific use of the term (Br√ºssow, 2016;Olesen and Alm, 2016). Here, we use the term to highlight changes in microbiome composition specifically correlated with disease states in threatened animals, without inferring a causative link between the two.

Dysbiosis can potentially result in highly dissimilar microbial profiles among individuals of the same species which could have important implications for drug metabolism (Zaneveld et al., 2017). However, reproducible and predictable microbiome profiles have also been observed in association with certain diseases (reviewed in Gilbert et al., 2018), in mammals with similar diets (Muegge et al., 2011;Moeller et al., 2013;Delsuc et al., 2014) and in multiple captive primate hosts (Clayton et al., 2016). The study of microbiome dysbiosis has extended in recent years to threatened animals such as giant pandas (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) (Zhao et al., 2017b), chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) (Barbian et al., 2018), and amphibians (reviewed in Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016). However, it remains unclear whether these cases of dysbiosis represent the cause or result of disease. Further research is necessary to identify specific instances of microbial network collapse that lead to disease or exacerbate declining host health. While dysbiosis is a concept of heavy discussion, one may still observe significant changes to the microbiome without necessarily associating this with disease. Much research concerning the microbiomes of threatened animals investigates how external factors, such as habitat, behaviour and diet, can alter microbial community structure or composition. There remains speculation about whether these changes can negatively affect the host organism, particularly when microbes with specific metabolic functions are lost.

div.head: Impact of habitat degradation and climate change
Habitat degradation
div.p: Sub-optimal habitats can alter dietary habits in primates, contributing to reduced microbial diversity and variable community composition in the gastrointestinal tract (Amato et al., 2013;Barelli et al., 2015). For example, the gut microbiome of red colobus monkeys (Procolobus gordonorum) inhabiting degraded habitats lacked the metabolic pathways necessary to detoxify plant xenobiotics common to folivorous digestion (Barelli et al., 2015). Loss of diverse plant taxa in natural habitats could lead to a reduction of key plant-degrading microbiota, in turn reducing functional capacity of the host gut microbiome in threatened species (Borb√≥n-Garc√≠a et al., 2017). Losing the ability to process such compounds could conceivably affect host survivorship if these animals are translocated to a new environment, such as a monitored reserve, making conservation an increasingly difficult task.

Habitat degradation not only affects the gut microbiome, but can noticeably impact the skin microbiome of amphibians, increasing susceptibility to infectious disease (reviewed in Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Krynak et al., 2016). The amphibian skin microbiome varies with ecomorphology and relies on natural surroundings to replenish its diversity and recruit rare environmental microbes that provide important services to the host (Loudon et al., 2014;Walke et al., 2014;Bletz et al., 2017a). Habitat degradation and climate change could potentially disrupt vital microbial reservoirs and prevent adequate recruitment of microbes with protective functions, thereby endangering amphibian health and immune defence systems (Loudon et al., 2014;Longo et al., 2015;Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Krynak et al., 2016;Kueneman et al., 2016;Hughey et al., 2017). Such disruptions may also encourage colonisation by invasive microbial species which compete with the vulnerable cutaneous populations for resources.

div.head: Climate change
div.p: Coral reefs are among the most sensitive ecosystems impacted by climate change because corals exist in habitats already close to their thermal threshold. During thermal stress the symbiotic relationship between coral and its endosymbiotic dinoflagellate partner (Symbiodinium sp.) breaks down, a process known as bleaching.

Multiple mass coral bleaching events have been reported with increasing frequency since the 1980s. These events have been attributed to climate change and result in extensive coral mortality and reef habitat degradation (Hughes et al., 2017). Rising seawater temperatures have also been linked to shifts in the coral microbiome, contributing to altered metabolic function, reduced fitness and increased disease susceptibility of the holobiont (Bourne et al., 2008;Bourne et al., 2009;Mera and Bourne, 2018). Numerous studies have documented significant microbiome changes in corals (and sponges) at high seawater temperatures, particularly those with low heat tolerance, which lead to increased pathogen virulence and impairment of host defence mechanisms (Fan et al., 2013;Lee et al., 2015;Blanquer et al., 2016;Glasl et al., 2016;Ziegler et al., 2017;Ramsby et al., 2018). Often, microbial community shifts can precede visual signs of bleaching and necrosis (Bourne et al., 2008). For example, Glasl et al. (2016) found that visually healthy corals treated with antibiotics to disrupt the microbiome of the surface mucus layer became bleached and necrotic upon re-introduction to their natural reef. Recovery of the holobiont was determined by the degree of change in the mucus microbiome. Anthropogenic activity (overfishing and nutrient pollution) can also negatively impact corals by altering the microbiome, leading to increased sensitisation to predation, temperature and bacterial opportunism (Zaneveld et al., 2016).

Climate change (in the form of rising environmental temperatures) can also reduce gut microbiome diversity in ectotherms (Bestion et al., 2017) and may promote opportunistic pathogenicity in previously benign microbial taxa (pathobionts) (Ritchie, 2006;reviewed in Bahrndorff et al., 2016).The microbiome's potentially harmful influence on the survival of threatened species in continually degrading habitats could create cascading health effects that may increase risk of local extinctions. Microbial community changes in animals occupying degraded habitats are similarly observed in captive animals, especially where enclosures lack important natural structures that may usually serve as key microbial reservoirs (Loudon et al., 2014).

div.head: Captivity alters the microbiome
div.p: Housing threatened animals in captivity is an essential component of global conservation strategies. Captive centres such as zoos provide safe, controlled conditions for breeding programmes, injured animals, and critically endangered species that require protection or have no available habitat. These centres also enable education of a wide public audience to raise awareness about local and global conservation endeavours. It is widely acknowledged, however, that zoos are limited in their ability to provide large spaces for naturally roaming species. Smaller enclosures can often lead to altered animal behaviour not observed in their wild counterparts. In some species, captivity is also associated with lower reproductive rates and poor health (Gore et al., 2001;Amato et al., 2016;Tubbs et al., 2016;Ushida et al., 2016;Wasimuddin et al., 2017).

Numerous studies have documented changes in gut and cutaneous microbiomes between captive and wild cohorts of threatened species, from amphibians and dugongs (Dugong dugong) to non-human primates (Eigeland et al., 2012;Amato et al., 2013;Loudon et al., 2014;Clayton et al., 2016;Delport et al., 2016;McKenzie et al., 2017;Metcalf et al., 2017;Song et al., 2017;Jia et al., 2018) (Fig. 2). These findings present important implications for the current management of threatened species in captivity, especially if such changes reflect a shift to an imbalanced or dysbiotic microbiome. Many studies describe a decrease in microbial community diversity (alpha diversity) and/or significant differences in community composition (beta-diversity) in captive hosts, such as the red-shanked douc and Andean bear (Tremarctos ornatus) ( Fig. 1) (Eigeland et al., 2012;Amato et al., 2013;Kong et al., 2014;Cheng et al., 2015;Amato et al., 2016;Clayton et al., 2016 Kohl et al., 2017;McKenzie et al., 2017). However, an increase in microbial diversity with captivity has been observed for the Panama golden frog (Atelopus zeteki), red-crowned crane (Grus japonensis), Japanese giant salamander (Andrias japonicus), and Rhinocertidae (Becker et al., 2014;Xie et al., 2016;Bletz et al., 2017b;McKenzie et al., 2017). In these cases, it is possible that low sample sizes led to a spurious effect, but it is also possible that captivity does lead to an increase in microbial diversity for some animals. While this increase could be debated, microbial community composition (Shannon diversity measure for both richness and evenness) differed significantly between all studied captive and wild populations except for the giant salamander. Interestingly, the gut microbiomes of koala (Phascolarctos cinereus), three toad species (Atelopus elegans, A. limosus, A. spurrelli) and several species from the families Bovidae, Giraffidae, Myrmecophagidae, and Orycteropodidae do not vary significantly with captivity (Alfano et al., 2015;Flechas et al., 2017;McKenzie et al., 2017). Perry et al. (2017) also found no significant effect of supplemental feeding on the gut microbiome of an endangered New Zealand parrot, the kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (Strigops habroptilus). Once again, it is important to consider whether sample size may affect these findings, yet in some cases the microbiome may be more resilient to change compared to other species.

Differences observed in gut and cutaneous microbiomes with captivity are often attributed to simpler or altered diets, sterile environmental surroundings, and antibiotic or medical treatment. This issue has been addressed in a broad range of vertebrate taxa, including primates (Fogel, 2015;Amato et al., 2016;Clayton et al., 2016;Stumpf et al., 2016;Su et al., 2016;Hale et al., 2018), dugongs (Eigeland et al., 2012), ptarmigans (Lagopus spp.) (Ushida et al., 2016), lizards (Jiang et al., 2017;Kohl et al., 2017) Simple and homogenous low-fibre diets in captivity may be responsible for altered microbial community structure and function compared to the diverse diets of wild animals, especially in herbivores. Symbiotic gut microbes in herbivorous species are essential for the digestion of recalcitrant plant fibres and play a key role in degrading plant toxins that are harmful to the host (Garcia-Amado et al., 2007;Amato et al., 2013;Amato et al., 2016;Borb√≥n-Garc√≠a et al., 2017). Gastrointestinal microbes thereby enable access to nutritional plant resources that are otherwise unobtainable for the animal host. The loss of such essential microbial taxa from the gastrointestinal tract in captivity due to insufficient dietary variation could alter the functional capacity and nutritional efficiency of the microbiome (Amato et al., 2013;Amato et al., 2016;Clayton et al., 2016;Borb√≥n-Garc√≠a et al., 2017). A functionallylimited microbiome could in turn have severe health implications for the host, which may have lost key toxin-and plant-degrading capabilities (Amato et al., 2013). In some cases, the captive microbiome profile may represent a stable multi-state that has no negative health implications for the host. However, bacterial species that provide essential functions in the wild may not regain dominance after being outcompeted in captivity, leading to potentially severe health implications for reintroduction schemes.

Gastrointestinal, respiratory and cardiac disorders are frequent barriers to the effective management of captive threatened species and may be influenced by dysbiotic microbiomes (Amato et al., 2013;Becker et al., 2015;Wan et al., 2016;McKenzie et al., 2017;Wasimuddin et al., 2017;Hale et al., 2018). Usually-benign microbiota may exhibit pathogenicity in captive animals under periods of stress, infection or antibiotic treatment which compromise the immune system and alter normal microbial community structure (Wan et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2017b). Abnormal diets may also contribute to the development of disease and infection in captive species by potentiating microbiome change (Wasimuddin et al., 2017;Hale et al., 2018). Microbiome alterations have been correlated with disease in the following species housed in captivity: red-crowned cranes (Xie et al., 2016), Yangtze finless porpoises (Neophocaena phocaenoides) with respiratory infection (Wan et al., 2016), gorillas (Gorilla gorilla gorilla) suffering from cardiac disease (Krynak et al., 2017), giant pandas with canine distemper virus (Zhao et al., 2017b), and gastrointestinal illness in doucs (P. nemaeus) (Amato et al., 2016). Further research is necessary to identify whether these changes reflect a cause or merely a result of the disease state. Nevertheless, a dysfunctional microbiome is likely to affect drug metabolism and potentiate disease symptoms.

Artificial habitats and sterility in captive enclosures and aquaria can also significantly alter the host microbiome (Cheng et al., 2015;Wan et al., 2016). Amphibians that supplement or derive their cutaneous microbial community from the surrounding environment are particularly vulnerable to skin microbiome alteration in captivity. Provision of natural substrata can mitigate changes to the amphibian cutaneous microbiome, enabling captive hosts to retain a substantial portion of the wild-type microbiome profile (Becker et al., 2014;Loudon et al., 2014). Enclosures that mimic natural habitats are therefore more likely to encourage healthier microbiomes in captive species, and potentially decrease pathogen susceptibility (Bletz et al., 2017b).

The modification of microbiome function and stability in captivity could in some cases reflect a state of dysbiosis and potentially reduce the success rate of breeding, translocation and reintroduction schemes by impacting host health and subsequent survival in the wild (Redford et al., 2012;Becker et al., 2014;Bahrndorff et al., 2016;Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Stumpf et al., 2016;Colston, 2017;Kohl et al., 2017). Reintroducing animals with modified microbiomes may increase their susceptibility to pathogens and enteric disease in the wild, undermining previous conservation and health management endeavours (McKenzie et al., 2017). Released animals susceptible to infection could also negatively affect sympatric wild species that can transmit shared microbiota among one another (Moeller et al., 2013). Furthermore, the transfer of pathogens and antibiotic resistance to wild populations during translocation programmes could possibly create collateral health effects. The available evidence suggests a key role for the microbiome in host health, with potentially important consequences for the survival of threatened species in a changing environment (Bahrndorff et al., 2016), particularly in specialised taxa.

div.head: Antibiotics: a double-edged sword for conservation?
div.p: Antibiotics are frequently used to treat pathogenic bacterial infection in humans and other animals, yet accumulating evidence suggests antibiotic treatment can disrupt the microbiome and impair host health, increasing susceptibility to secondary infections and promoting the development of disorders such as obesity (Looft and Allen, 2012;Hernandez et al., 2013;Nami et al., 2015;Br√ºssow, 2016;Gasparrini et al., 2016). The recurring discovery of antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains across multiple animal taxa has also prompted concerns over excessive antibiotic use, yet there are limited studies on the effects of antibiotics in threatened species. Koalas administered antibiotics for chlamydia infection showed severe microbiome changes, including the loss of vital tannin-degrading bacteria from individuals that died following treatment (Dahlhausen et al., 2018). Antibiotic treatment in western lowland gorillas (G. g. gorilla) significantly altered gut microbiome stability and relative bacterial abundance (Vlƒçkov√° et al., 2016), though functional capacity may not always be impaired (Becker et al., 2015;Br√ºssow, 2016;Vlƒçkov√° et al., 2016). Further studies are required to investigate the potential collateral damage that antibiotic treatment may inflict on threatened species.

Antibiotic resistance in threatened wildlife is also of increasing concern for conservation management. Threatened animals can acquire antibiotic resistance externally in natural habitats contaminated with resistant bacterial strains, as observed in Australian sea lions (Neophoca cinerea) (Delport et al., 2015), brush-tailed rock wallabies (Petrogale penicillata) (Power et al., 2013), Iberian lynx (Lynx pardinus) (Sousa et al., 2014), Gal√°pagos reptiles (Wheeler et al., 2012), and various other wildlife (Cristobal-Azkarate et al., 2014;Jobbins and Alexander, 2015). Additionally, the acquisition of antibiotic resistance during translocation operations could spread to, and potentially have catastrophic consequences for, na√Øve wild populations (Power et al., 2013). Consequently, even with careful management of antibiotic treatment, acquired resistance remains a major health consideration for conservation strategies. Without practical antibiotic alternatives, the incidence of antibiotic-resistant diseases may increase rapidly in threatened and susceptible wildlife.

div.head: Manipulating the microbiome to enhance host health
Describing the microbiome
div.p: The initial step in any microbiome analysis is to collect a representative sample. For microorganisms associated with animal hosts, faecal samples are typically used as a proxy for the gut microbiome due to their ease of collection and non-invasive nature (Ley et al., 2008;Muegge et al., 2011;McKenzie et al., 2017). Faeces offer a reasonable representation of the colonic (large intestine) microbiome, at least for hindgut-fermenting animals, but are less reflective of the small intestine (Yasuda et al., 2015). For birds and reptiles cloacal swabs offer an alternative if faeces are not available, but may be less representative of the colonic microbiome (Videvall et al., 2018). Other non-invasive sampling approaches include the taking of skin swabs from amphibians (McKenzie et al., 2012), and collection of blow samples from marine mammals by flying a drone through the expelled water vapour when an animal resurfaces (Apprill et al., 2017). Preserving the integrity of a collected sample is also of paramount importance but can be particularly challenging in field situations, such as during the collection of primate faecal matter in remote tropical forest locations (Hayakawa et al., 2018b). Various strategies, including the use of specialised commercial kits, have been employed to overcome such challenges (Hale et al., 2016;Song et al., 2016;Hayakawa et al., 2018b). Depending on the nature of downstream analyses, the following step often involves extracting DNA from the collected samples, generally via mechanical or enzymatic cell lysis. Microbial community composition is then typically determined via the sequencing of specific, PCR-amplified genomic regions such as 16S ribosomal RNA genes for bacteria and archaea, and the internally transcribed spacer (ITS) region of fungi (Kuczynski et al., 2011;Mallick et al., 2017) (Fig. 3). Contemporary high-throughput DNA sequencing approaches allow for the rapid and relatively cost-effective analysis of such 'marker genes'. Although some inferences about potential microbiome function can be gleaned from analysis of 16S rRNA gene data (Langille et al., 2013), a more complete picture can be obtained through the direct sequencing of all DNA (i.e. not involving PCR) (Segata et al., 2013;Mallick et al., 2017) (Fig. 3). While this non-targeted, 'shotgun metagenomics' approach provides valuable insights into microbial community function and metabolism, it is not without its challenges. For many sample types there may be a high degree of contaminating host DNA within the obtained DNA extract, meaning that data sets can be dominated by non-microbial sequences. Other, complementary 'meta-omic' techniques can be applied to the analysis of gene expression (metatranscriptomics), proteins (metaproteomics) and metabolites (metametabolomics) (Gutleben et al., 2018).

div.head: Creating microbiome indices and baselines
div.p: Microbiome engineering is an emerging field of research in which the aim is to improve host health (and possibly fitness) in dysbiotic individuals by manipulating microbial community composition (Mueller and Sachs, 2015). However, to effectively manage or manipulate the microbiome requires prior knowledge of a healthy microbial community profile (Br√ºssow, 2016). It is therefore essential to identify normal microbiome variation among individuals that is not associated with infection or disease (Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016). Microbial communities are known to vary among individuals in response to both internal and abiotic factors such as genetics, age, behaviour, diet, social interactions, habitat and climate (reviewed in Amato, 2013;Alberdi et al., 2016;Colston and Jackson, 2016;Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016). Yet microbiome composition typically varies more among different species, exhibiting strong species-specific profiles (Ley et al., 2008;Colston andJackson, 2016, non-human primates reviewed in Clayton et al., 2018), though this is not always the case (see Littman et al., 2009;Bletz et al., 2017a;Varela et al., 2018).

In addition to considering inter-individual and inter-species variation, recent research has looked to describe a 'core microbiome' of microbial taxa that are present in all or most (e.g. > 90%) individuals of a particular species (Ainsworth et al., 2015;Chu and Vollmer, 2016;Astudillo-Garcia et al., 2017;Hughey et al., 2017;Prado-Irwin et al., 2017;Zhao et al., 2017a). For example, Apprill et al. (2017) observed a core microbiome comprising 25 microbial species present in all humpback whale (Megaptera novaeangliae) blow samples collected from two separate populations. Of these 25 core species, 20 were most closely related to microbes commonly found in other marine mammals. Microbes present within all members of a species potentially provide beneficial services to (and receive benefits from) the host. Their presence or absence may therefore be useful indicators or biomarkers of host health, although further research in unhealthy individuals is necessary to determine whether core members do indeed differ with disease state. It is also worth considering that functional rather than taxonomic variation in the microbiome may be most meaningful for host health. While microbial community composition often varies considerably among individuals of a species, microbiome function may not (Turnbaugh et al., 2009). Such 'functional redundancy' describes the capacity for different microbial species to carry out similar metabolic functions. Hence, disruptions to vital functional processes could provide useful biomarkers for disease and infection that vary less Fig. 3. Experimental procedures for sequencing microbial DNA. Taxonomic identification can be obtained via PCR amplification of the 16S rRNA gene (a gene region conserved in all bacterial and archaeal species), or by shotgun metagenomics whereby random segments of DNA are sequenced from the entire microbial sample. By sequencing all microbial DNA, shotgun metagenomics can also provide information about the potential function of the microbiome. Other approaches can be used to study microbiome gene expression (metatranscriptomics), protein production (metaproteomics) and metabolite production (metametabolomics).

between individuals than microbial species composition. For the majority of threatened animal species, functional data about the microbiome have not yet been obtained (notable exceptions within threatened animals include non-hominid primates (reviewed in Stumpf et al., 2016;Liu et al., 2018), kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (Waite et al., 2018), giant panda (Guo et al., 2018), and the Andean bear (Borb√≥n-Garc√≠a et al., 2017)).

Creating individual microbiome health profiles may be feasible for critically endangered species with low numbers, such as the kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (< 150 birds), to help improve host health. However, such a strategy is not practical for species with greater numbers. Rather, creating a health index (Apprill et al., 2014;Apprill et al., 2017) of the microbiomes of randomly sampled, healthy individuals could help conservation managers identify instances of dysbiosis and community collapse. Creating microbiome indices may also prevent the future identification of "abnormal pathogens" which may in fact be part of the natural microbiota of a particular animal, and could unnecessarily halt translocation efforts (Shaw et al., 2014). Microbial-based health indexes could potentially provide an early detection system for infection or disease before harmful physiological symptoms develop by identifying key health-related biomarkers (Apprill et al., 2014;Apprill, 2017;Glasl et al., 2017). For example, significant changes in coral and sponge microbiomes can precede obvious visual signs of bleaching, tissue damage, or declining health under thermal stress (Fan et al., 2013;Lee et al., 2015;Blanquer et al., 2016;Glasl et al., 2016;Ramsby et al., 2018). Establishment of microbial baselines has thus been suggested for monitoring the health of coral reef ecosystems using corals as indicator organisms of poor water quality (Bourne et al., 2016;Glasl et al., 2017;Glasl et al., 2018;Roitman et al., 2018).

Microbiome surveillance could further inform current management programmes of an animal's geographic range and migration through forest corridors and oceans (Apprill et al., 2014;Stumpf et al., 2016). If threatened populations exhibit unique microbial signatures they could potentially be useful to programmes monitoring animal movement, illegal trafficking and poaching, allowing the identification of target populations and more efficient allocation of resources (Degnan et al., 2012;Song et al., 2016;Stumpf et al., 2016). Such an approach mirrors the use of environmental DNA (eDNA) surveys for detection of invasive species in environments which are difficult to monitor directly (Rees et al., 2014).

Baseline knowledge of healthy microbiome profiles in threatened species would also aid bioengineering research that looks to enhance microbiome function, thereby improving host performance or fitness (Mueller and Sachs, 2015). The inclusion of 'meta-omic' methods in microbiome research can elucidate key functional roles performed by specific microbial taxa, as well as the microbiome as a whole (Rebollar et al., 2016;Hernandez-Gomez et al., 2017;Waite et al., 2018), identifying target areas for manipulation endeavours (Mueller and Sachs, 2015). Microbiome engineering, potentially through the provision of probiotics or prebiotics, could theoretically improve the health and overall fitness of threatened species (Mueller and Sachs, 2015;Bahrndorff et al., 2016); this represents a promising new area of research for conservation management.

div.head: Diet and prebiotics
div.p: Research in humans has revealed that diet can rapidly alter the gut microbiome (David et al., 2014;Peddada, 2017), with far-reaching implications for human health and disease (reviewed in Carding et al., 2015;Marchesi et al., 2016;Singh et al., 2017). A recent study in captive southern white rhinos (SWR) (Ceratotherium simum simum) found that a high concentration of phytoestrogens (a plant chemical commonly found in alfalfa and soy) in their diet was at least partly responsible for the low reproductive success of females (Tubbs et al., 2016;Tubbs et al., 2017). By comparing the faeces of SWR and onehorned rhinos (Rhinoceros unicornis), which by comparison breed well in captivity, researchers found phytoestrogens were highly elevated in the faeces of SWR despite being fed identical diets. Zoo keepers subsequently replaced the high-phytoestrogen pellets with low-phytoestrogen grass-based pellets and switched the majority of the SWR's diet to Bermuda or Sudan hay. Following this diet modification, two previously infertile female SWR were able to conceive and gave birth to healthy offspring. When this study was presented at the 2018 meeting of the American Society for Microbiology (reported by Reardon (2018) in Nature News), researchers speculated that the gut microbiota of SWR was not adept at breaking down phytoestrogens, and are currently investigating this further.

Dietary supplements that encourage the growth of healthy microbial communities have also become increasingly popular, particularly for production animals. For example, feed enzymes have been successful in altering the gut microbiome in pigs and poultry to promote animal health and reduce the incidence of diseases such as post-weaning colibacillosis and necrotic enteritis (reviewed in Kiarie et al., 2013;Foo et al., 2017). The administration of chemical modifiers such as feed enzymes and prebiotics aims to promote the dominance of specific bacterial species by providing substrates essential to the growth of target microbes (Schrezenmeir and de Vrese, 2001;Marchesi et al., 2016;Foo et al., 2017). Initial studies in mouse models also indicate the potential for supplements such as prebiotics to reshape the gut microbiome (reviewed in Foo et al., 2017). Dysbiosis of gut microbiomes in captive threatened species could be reduced using diet management schemes to enhance recruitment of beneficial microbes. For example, carotenoid dietary supplements can significantly enhance the diversity and composition of the cutaneous microbiome of Australian Southern corroboree frogs (Pseudophyrne corroboree), which may boost host immune function and resilience to pathogens (Edwards et al., 2017). Similar supplements could substantially improve animal health in captivity and subsequent reintroduction success, calling for further research in other threatened taxa. Although supplemental feeding did not alter gut microbiome structure in kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (Perry et al., 2017), its potential for health management remains unknown. Improving or maintaining microbe-host interactions through diet alterations that encourage positive changes in host health represents a non-invasive management approach for threatened species that can potentially be straightforward and relatively inexpensive.

div.head: Probiotics
div.p: Probiotics are live microorganisms (usually bacteria) that are administered with the aim of benefitting host health (Schrezenmeir and de Vrese, 2001;Foo et al., 2017;McKenzie et al., 2018), and have been used to treat disease and promote pathogen resistance in various animal taxa. In humans, a combination of probiotic bacterial strains successfully induced remission of the gut diseases ulcerative colitis and pouchitis (Mimura et al., 2004;Zocco et al., 2006;Sood et al., 2009;Mardini and Grigorian, 2014;Schulberg and De Cruz, 2016;Nishida et al., 2018). Probiotics have also promoted weight gain and beneficial microbiome function in sheep and dairy calves (Schofield et al., 2018), and have conferred disease protection to various aquaculture and poultry species (McKenzie et al., 2018). In turtles (Trachemys scripta scripta and Sternotherus odoratus), probiotics promoted positive growth effects on gut histology and shell mineralisation (Rawski et al., 2016). While probiotics are currently administered to hand-reared kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç chicks, to date there has been no systematic assessment of the treatment's efficacy.

A recent study by Tsuchida et al. (2018) isolated two unique strains of Lactobacillus, common lactic acid bacteria beneficial to humans, from western lowland and mountain (G. beringei beringei) gorillas. L. gorillae strains were identified as competent plant fermenters and displayed inhibitory activity towards a pathogenic strain of Escherichia coli. Notably, strains of L. gorillae isolated from wild gorillas were better at fermentation and at inhibiting E. coli than strains isolated from captive gorillas, with strains obtained from wild mountain gorillas exhibiting the greatest antibacterial activity. The authors therefore proposed that L. gorillae isolated from wild mountain gorillas could be a potential probiotic candidate for captive individuals.

In threatened amphibians, the augmentation of cutaneous microbiomes with probiotics has become a primary focal point in the treatment of disease and dysbiosis (Bletz et al., 2013;Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Kueneman et al., 2016;Woodhams et al., 2016;McKenzie et al., 2018). Such probiotic therapies aim to enhance survival of threatened species by increasing the ability of the microbiome to resist and mitigate pathogenic infection (Bletz et al., 2013;Woodhams et al., 2014;Woodhams et al., 2016). Chytridiomycosis, caused by the fungal pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), has resulted in the rapid decline, and in some cases extinction, of many amphibian species, and is thus of great concern to conservation management (Jim√©nez and Sommer, 2016;Walke and Belden, 2016;Woodhams et al., 2016). Symbiont bacteria of the cutaneous microbiome can promote disease resistance by regulating host immune response, or through the direct production of antifungal and antibacterial toxins (Woodhams et al., 2016;reviewed in McKenzie et al., 2018). The introduction of probiotic strains can improve microbiome structure and function, and promote host immunity in diseased or dysbiotic individuals (Muletz et al., 2012;Woodhams et al., 2014;Woodhams et al., 2016). In captivity, the loss of beneficial skin microbes from endangered boreal toads (Anaxyrus boreas) is directly linked to increased Bd loads on the skin, but treatment with anti-Bd probiotic bacteria can boost host survivorship (Kueneman et al., 2016). Much amphibian-based microbiome research is currently focused on identifying suitable probiotics that are effective over a wide range of species, Bd strains, and environmental conditions (Woodhams et al., 2014;Woodhams et al., 2016;Bletz et al., 2017a). A combination of microbiome-enhancing therapies will likely create the most effective treatment for chytridiomycosis infection (Woodhams et al., 2016).

Preliminary probiotic treatment and enrichment of beneficial skin microbes has also been performed on little brown bats (Myotis lucifugus) infected with White-nose Syndrome. Microbiome treatment improved bat survival and reduced the severity of infection (Cheng et al., 2017;Lemieux-Labont√© et al., 2017). Knowledge derived from these studies should help facilitate development of microbiome therapies for other threatened taxa. For example, microbiome manipulation has been proposed for corals as one means to increase their resilience to environmental challenges such as increased seawater temperatures, with shuffling of their Symbiodinium community and other microbial partners conferring increased thermal tolerance (van Oppen et al., 2015;Damjanovic et al., 2017;Peixoto et al., 2017;Torda et al., 2017;Bang et al., 2018). A preliminary microbiome study on critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle eggs (Eretmochelys imbricata) identified specific microbes with anti-pathogenic activity that could prove to be useful probiotics for hawksbill conservation (Sarmiento-Ramirez et al., 2014). In principle, probiotic therapy in threatened species could enhance current conservation management strategies by mitigating and preventing pathogenic infection, aiding gastrointestinal recovery from antibiotic-related disruptions, or increasing resilience to environmental challenges (Stumpf et al., 2016;Shi et al., 2018).

div.head: Faecal microbiota transplants
div.p: Faecal microbiota transplants consist of replacing or supplementing the gut microbiomes of diseased/unhealthy individuals with faecal microbiota from healthy individuals. In humans, faecal transplants consistently re-established healthy microbial communities in patients with recurrent Clostridioides difficile-associated diarrhoea (Kassam et al., 2013;Kao et al., 2017;reviewed in Nishida et al., 2018). New evidence suggests that even sterile faecal filtrate transfers are effective in treating C. difficile infection, as well as reducing the risk of infection and metabolic diseases in vulnerable patients that is usually associated with the transfer of live faecal microbiota (Ott et al., 2017). In children with autism spectrum disorder, microbiota transfer therapy significantly improved gastrointestinal and behavioural symptoms, with benefits persisting eight weeks after the end of the treatment (Kang et al., 2017). Faecal transplants (administered orally, and euphemistically referred to as competitive exclusion) have also been administered in poultry following demonstrated successes in protecting birds against common diseases (Schneitz, 2005;reviewed in McKenzie et al., 2018).

Despite the success of human faecal transplants in the treatment of C. difficile-associated diarrhoea, and its suggested use for other microbiome-related diseases (Br√ºssow, 2016;Foo et al., 2017), this approach has not been widely explored with threatened species. We know of only a handful of studies which have attempted to restore gut microbiomes with oral faecal inoculation, including in endangered dugongs (Eigeland et al., 2012) and kƒÅkƒÅp≈ç (Waite et al., 2013). While the latter did not explicitly test changes in the gut microbiome, the dugong study reported no changes after treatment. However, recent research presented at the 2018 American Society for Microbiology meeting suggests faecal transplants between koalas consuming different eucalyptus species may help alter dietary preferences by changing the gut microbiome profile (reported by Reardon (2018) in Nature News). Koalas consuming the less nutritious messmate eucalyptus (Eucalyptus obliqua) harboured different gut microbes to those eating mana gum (E. viminalis), and it was suggested that faecal transplants may help facilitate dietary expansion and aid conservation programmes which translocate koalas from degrading habitats to new areas with different eucalyptus species.

Together, prebiotics, probiotics and faecal transplants have been suggested as disease preventatives and potential antibiotic alternatives by promoting gut microbiome health (Waite et al., 2013;Allen et al., 2014;Nami et al., 2015;Br√ºssow, 2016;Schulberg and De Cruz, 2016;Foo et al., 2017;Li et al., 2017). Incorporating microbiome engineering into current conservation strategies may help improve threatened species' health and survival, and potentially increase the success rate of breeding programmes, translocations and reintroductions (reviewed in Redford et al., 2012) (Fig. 4). We list below future research priorities and directions.

6.6. Key areas for future research 1. Construct microbiome health indices for threatened species that could help identify microbial community changes which may lead to host vulnerability and disease. 2. Investigate whether specific instances of dysbiosis potentiate or exacerbate disease upon pathogen infection, and identify microbial species or functions that could be used as biomarkers of health and disease. 3. Investigate factors that contribute to captive and wild animal microbiome health, and improve diet, medical treatments and surrounding habitat to reduce stress and prevent introduction of, or shifts to, disease states. 4. Trial modified diets, introduction of natural environmental substrates, and/or probiotic treatments to help facilitate or maintain beneficial microbiome composition in threatened animals. 5. Research the safety and efficacy of potential faecal microbiota or sterile faecal filtrate transplants in other threatened species where it could potentially improve host health, and in future possibly help expand the microbiome's digestive capacity.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: Rescuing animals from extinction often involves bringing animals into captivity and intensively managing populations and ecosystems. In historical conservation practice, the prevailing approach was to strip these animals of parasites and microbes in order to 'protect' them from disease (Dunn, 2009). A classic example is the extinction of Colpocephalum californianus, a host-specific louse on once critically endangered California condors (Gymnogyps californianus), that was purposely removed from captive animals (R√≥zsa and Vas, 2014). With a new understanding of the complexity of host-associated microbes and the many as yet undiscovered positive health aspects of these symbionts, it is critical to embrace a paradigm shift for how we approach protection of threatened wildlife along with their microbiomes. Co-extinction of parasites, microbiota, and mutualists could potentially accelerate the decline of threatened wildlife as well as dampen the success of costly conservation efforts. Throughout this manuscript we have further highlighted that changes to the composition of a given animal's microbiome are highly variable between species. While we may attempt to ameliorate microbiome changes in a selection of target species, this knowledge should not be extrapolated to all other species when we lack fundamental information regarding how microbiomes in even closely related species may respond differently under similar conditions. For some wildlife, such as amphibians and primates, we are gaining a better understanding about the mechanics of how to achieve 'microbiome rescue'. For many other wildlife groups, more basic research is sorely needed, particularly for understanding the dimensions of dysbiosis and its causes (sensu Zaneveld et al., 2017). Fig. 4. An overview of the potential causes of dysbiosis and how microbiome engineering could conceivably help improve microbiome health and resilience, for example by conferring increased fitness and immune response on the threatened animal host.

div.head: Glossary
div.p: Microorganisms: single-celled, microscopic organisms such as bacteria, archaea, protozoa and fungi Host: multicellular organism that provides a habitat for microorganisms to colonise e.g. humans Microbiome: community of microorganisms (including their total genetic material) in a specific environment or space e.g. the gut or skin Dysbiosis: breakdown or collapse of the microbial community with typically negative implications for the host Prebiotics: substrates or food that support the growth and nourishment of 'good' bacteria in the gut Probiotics: a dietary supplement comprised of live microbial cultures that is deemed beneficial to host health Facultative: symbionts that are not strictly required for host survival Fitness: a measure of reproductive success in the context of evolutionary biology.

Individuals that are best adapted to the current environment are more likely to produce offspring and contribute more genes to subsequent generations (i.e. they are 'fitter') Ecomorphology: relationship between an organism's ecology and its phenotypic traits Microbiome engineering: deliberate manipulation of the microbiome with the aim to create beneficial microbial ecosystems that improve or enhance host health and performance Meta-omics: refers to approaches used in the study of genes (genomics and transcriptomics), proteins (proteomics) and metabolites (metabolomics) to understand the wider function of a given system
